comments.body: Why not adding a comment to explicate that this is a non-optimize form of `SBStructProj`
Good idea. I'll do that.

Given that we need to change it anyway, let's spell it out. I also think speaking of "contract observers" and "choice observers" is somewhat inconsistent. It should either be "template observers" and "choice observers" or "contract observers" and "exercise observers". I heavily prefer the former.
```suggestion
      val templateObservers = extractParties(args.get(4))
```

Why not defining a an abstract class for `OnLedgerBuiltin` ?  Something like :

```scala
sealed abstract class OnLedgerBuiltin(arity: Int) extends SBuiltin(arity) with Product {
    
    protected def execute(
        args: util.ArrayList[SValue],
        machine: Machine,
        onLedger: OnLedger
    ): Unit

    final override def execute(args: util.ArrayList[SValue], machine: Machine): Unit =
      machine.withOnLedger(productPrefix)(execute(args, machine, _))
  }
```
sounds good, let me give it a try
Added.

```suggestion
        onLedger: OnLedger,
    ): Unit =
```
You really love your trailing commas :slightly_smiling_face:
Was the `byKey` argument completely unused so far? Strange.
It is not dropped, it is move to the constructor of the builtin, line 899
Oh right. Thank you.
Maybe worth adding a comment that the reason we need to preserve the order is to preserve evaluation order?
done

I like how we pushed the sorting to compile time and keep it cheap at runtime.

I'm wondering if there's a way to avoid allocating a second array and reuse the `args` array instead? I couldn't come up quickly with a simple way myself though.
This seems to be a lot of complexity for a gain we can't properly quantify yet. Thus, I'd say it's not worthwhile for now.
Can we reuse the (almost) same definition from `Compiler.scala` here?
Do we really need this `sameElements` runtime check here? We're in full control of the code producing the structural record, aren't we?
dropped.

```suggestion
      machine.returnValue = args.get(0) match {
        case SContractId(cid) if machine.onLedger =>
             SOptional(Some(SText(cid.coid)))
        case _ => 
             SValue.SValue.None
      }  
```

This suggestion isnâ€™t correct.
1. You flipped the flag. You are returning `Some` in the `onLedger` case.
2. I would like to validate that we get a contract id even in the onLedger case. Just makes it easier to catch bugs.

My bad.
You could still use `SValue.SValue.None` that save you an allocation.
Thanks, changed!
did this

```suggestion
  protected def executePure(args: util.ArrayList[SValue]): SValue
```
We can't make this change, because we need `executePure` to be called from `SExpr` (in the coming ANF PR).

```suggestion
    Returns the resulting value */
```
thanks, fixed
Would it make sense to put some sort of inlining annotation here?
my earlier experience is that this kind of attempted micro optimization has no benefit.
This will be run on every value we get from the ledger and should hence rather be fast. Do we have any idea how expensive `contains` is? Does it get more expensive as we add more versions?

This is not particularly optimized. However I think this should be pretty negligible in comparison of the three passes of translations the value traverses (proto to java, java to LF Value, LF Value to Speedy values).

This gets also more expensive as we add more versions. If this becomes an issue,  we could just add a cache in `VersionRange#contains`
I see. Thanks for the explanation.

comments.body:
Thanks
Should this be the style output by `scalafmt` then?
(Or can that not happen because it requires the programmer to write the trailing `,` ?)

We had some issues with IntelliJ making scalafmt output a trailing comma before. This might now be fixed in the latest version of IntelliJ 2019; haven't tested it. I expect we'll need to upgrade to IntelliJ 2020 before we can, though, which means waiting for the Bazel plugin to support it.
Other `SBuiltin` implementations use `final def execute`. Should this one be `final` as well?
Good catch.
done

diffHunk:
@@ -24,8 +24,19 @@ import com.daml.lf.transaction.Node.{GlobalKey, KeyWithMaintainers}
 import scala.collection.JavaConverters._
 import scala.collection.immutable.TreeSet
 
+/**
+  Speedy builtins are stratified into two layers:
+  Parent: `SBuiltinMaybeHungry`, child: `SBuiltin` (which are never hungry).
+  Hungry means, may throw SpeedyHungry.
+
+  Non-hungry builtins can be treated specially because their evaluation is immediate.
+  This fact is used by the execution of the ANF expression form: `SELet1Builtin`.
+
+  The vast majority of the builtins are nevery hungry, and so they extend `SBuiltin`
+  There are 7 hungry builtins which extend `SBuiltinMaybeHungry`
+  */
 /** Speedy builtin functions */

comments.body: Is this `TODO` crucial for this PR to work or something you want to address in a follow-up PR?
Yup, we made this issue #6523
Does the `1` in `arity1` have a meaning? To me it looks just like `arity`.
Scala wont let this variable be named `arity`. I assume because it already in scope in a parent class. Hence the suffix `1`
I sadly understand.

Just to be a bit picky. following Scala convention you should not change capitalization when you rename import. 
Basically a package should start with lower case and Object should start with upper case.

comments.body:
@nickchapman-da @remyhaemmerle-da What's _operational_ the difference between
```scala
mbCoid.map(SContractId)
```
and
```scala
mbCoid.map { coid => SContractId(coid) }
```
In other words, why would you eta-expand? I've seen changes like this in other places too.

I do not think there is any operational difference. 
However  `machine.returnValue = SOptional(mbCoid.map(SContractId))` is more idiomatic.
should this be: `machine.returnValue = SV.None` ?
and some other places
The `machine.returnValue = ` is in line 343.

I don't understand why this code should have any effect, if the type signature in the commet of `SBSBeginCommit` is still up-to-date. Seeing that it extends `SBuiltin(2)`, there shouldn't be any contractIds in `args`. Am I missing something?
Or is it that the first argument of type `Party` can be a complex expression referring to contract IDs?

You are right. I was too quick. 
Anyway, I am not sure I can implement the check of freshness for scenarios. 
I will probably do a first pass without scenario, and see in a second time if it can be added .
contract id freshness is not does in case of scenarios.
rewritten.

comments.body: I wonder whether you want to check here that the contract ID in `args0` does not clash w.r.t. discriminators. If we reinterpret a tree, the contract ID might come from a `fetchByKey` construct which is translated into a fetch node only. So the fetched contract ID might come out of nowhere. But I'm not sure whether this can happen on this code path.

Here I do not want to check the contract in `args0`. 
The check of contract gathering by contract key should be done in  `SBULookupKey` (done) and in `SBUFetchKey` (currently missing)

Is the "positive" `ValueEnum(Some(id), ...)` missing?

Edit: Ah no, it's further down. Maybe colocate the two cases?

comments.body: It looks like this is only used for translating the input value of a DAML script. Why donâ€™t we just call `translateValue` directly for that (similarly to how we called `fromValue` before) instead of adding a new builtin that isnâ€™t used anywhere else?

The problem is that `translateValue` may throw exceptions to ask for the package. 
I do not know how to handle it. 
If you some idea, or if you want of fix you are welcome.
It only throws an exception if a package is not already in `compiledPackages` right? That will never happen for the script runner so we should be fine to just call it.

+  private def translateValue(machine: Machine, value: V[V.ContractId]): CtrlValue = {
+    def go(value0: V[V.ContractId]): SValue =
+      value0 match {
+        case V.ValueList(vs) => SList(vs.map[SValue](go))
+        case V.ValueContractId(coid) => SContractId(coid)
+        case V.ValueInt64(x) => SInt64(x)
+        case V.ValueNumeric(x) => SNumeric(x)
+        case V.ValueText(t) => SText(t)
+        case V.ValueTimestamp(t) => STimestamp(t)
+        case V.ValueParty(p) => SParty(p)
+        case V.ValueBool(b) => SBool(b)
+        case V.ValueDate(x) => SDate(x)
+        case V.ValueUnit => SUnit
+        case V.ValueRecord(Some(id), fs) =>
+          val fields = Name.Array.ofDim(fs.length)
+          val values = new util.ArrayList[SValue](fields.length)
+          fs.foreach {
+            case (optk, v) =>
+              optk match {
+                case None =>
+                  throw crash("SValue.fromValue: record missing field name")
+                case Some(k) =>
+                  fields(values.size) = k
+                  val _ = values.add(go(v))
+              }
+          }
+          SRecord(id, fields, values)
+        case V.ValueRecord(None, _) =>
+          crash("SValue.fromValue: record missing identifier")
+        case V.ValueStruct(fs) =>
+          val fields = Name.Array.ofDim(fs.length)
+          val values = new util.ArrayList[SValue](fields.length)
+          fs.foreach {
+            case (k, v) =>
+              fields(values.size) = k
+              val _ = values.add(go(v))
+          }
+          SStruct(fields, values)
+        case V.ValueVariant(None, _variant @ _, _value @ _) =>

+          crash("SValue.fromValue: enum without identifier")
+        case V.ValueOptional(mbV) =>

+            case None =>
+              throw SpeedyHungry(
+                SResultNeedPackage(
+                  id.packageId,
+                  pkg => {
+                    machine.compiledPackages = pkg
+                    machine.ctrl = translateValue(machine, value)

+                ))
+          }
+        case V.ValueEnum(Some(id), constructor) =>
+          machine.compiledPackages.getPackage(id.packageId) match {
+            case Some(pkg) =>
+              pkg.lookupIdentifier(id.qualifiedName).fold(crash, identity) match {
+                case Ast.DDataType(_, _, data: Ast.DataEnum) =>
+                  SEnum(id, constructor, data.constructorRank(constructor))
+                case _ =>
+                  crash(s"definition for variant $id not found")
+              }
+            case None =>
+              throw SpeedyHungry(
+                SResultNeedPackage(

+                  pkg => {
+                    machine.compiledPackages = pkg
+                    machine.ctrl = translateValue(machine, value)
+                  }
+                ))
+          }
+      }
+    CtrlValue(go(value))
+  }

comments.body: `asInstanceOf[STNat]` etc. might be faster.
The only penalty here is by tupling, which can be avoided by nesting `match`.
BTW, are you sure that doesn't allow unicode digits?
The answer is that it doesn't allow unicode digits: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html

allowing the leading `+` has the slight disadvantage that we do not have a canonical representation for `Int64` -- the same numbers can be represented in multiple ways. i'm on the fence on whether this is a good thing or not.
If we allow leading zeros, we have the same problem.
Yes, see my own comment below.

I believe we should not restrict parsing to canonical representation. For instance, the final user probably want to parse "1" and "01" in the same way.
Both Haskell and java (and any other languages I can think of) parse "01" and "1" in the same way.

Furthermore, this has no impact on determinism.
do you allow trailing / leading 0s? this regexp does. do we know what that means when parsing?

Please see tests 
https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/pull/1407/files#diff-ae9014deee9be354b39ebd26faa0150b

OK, so the answer is "yes". I'm really on the fence regarding canonical representation. For users it's clearly worse... so going with the current implementation is probably the right thing.

@hurryabit what do you think?
I'm not sure there's value in having a canonical representation for _parsing_. Being lenient seems fine to me.

Note, we are already lenient (though a bit less than here) when parsing decimals from protobu. We accept anything that matches 
``[+-]?[0-9]{1,28}(\.[0-9]{1,10})?``
@remyhaemmerle-da @bitonic Can you please confirm whether this is the right place to fill in the controllers for missing actors.
looks good.

To make sure the implied `toString` is benign in the face of future changes:

```suggestion
      machine.ctrl = CtrlValue(SText(s"'${v.value: String}'"))
```

I've discussed with @leo-da doing this as a rule, and replacing `s` in the future with one that only accepts some types for interpolation; for now this is a good stopgap.
